p: Overall, there is evidence that J. regia extracts have strong growth inhibitory and antibiofilm activity against many species of bacteria. Juglone, and an active compound from J. regia, has strong inhibitory activity against P. gingivalis and other oral pathogens, and extracts of the leaves and septa have low toxicity in vivo in mice and rats. More studies are needed to determine the antibacterial activity against a broader range of oral pathogens specifically, and to determine the in vivo effects on periodontitis.
